intro: Stachys czernjaevii, commonly known as the Czech mint, is a perennial herb native to Central and Eastern Europe. It belongs to the Lamiaceae family, which is characterized by square stems and aromatic leaves. The plant typically grows to a height of about 30–60 cm, with hairy, lance-shaped leaves that are often aromatic when crushed. Its flowers are small, tubular, and clustered in whorls, typically blooming in shades of purple or violet. Stachys czernjaevii is often found in moist meadows and along streambanks, where it thrives in partial to full sunlight.
